Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) = e^{i \\omega t} \\) where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( \\omega \\) is a real number frequency parameter. This function represents a complex exponential oscillation. Analyze the transformation with the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) defined by \\( \\mathcal{F}(z(t))(\\xi) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty e^{-i \\xi t} z(t) dt \\).

If an intervention modifies \\( z(t) \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) by applying a phase shift \\( \\phi \\), will the resulting Fourier transform be dependent solely on \\( \\omega \\)?
Explanation: Applying a phase shift \\( \\phi \\) to \\( z(t) \\) alters the original function to \\( e^{i (\\omega t + \\phi)} \\). Although the dominant frequency in the Fourier spectrum will still be \\( \\omega \\), the phase shift introduces a complex multiplier \\( e^{i \\phi} \\) affecting the entire transformed function by shifting its phase, hence it depends on both \\( \\omega \\) and \\( \\phi \\).
